awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  High-Purity Extraction of PET from Textile Waste
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to allow for the recycling of valuable materials from complex wastes that today cannot be recovered. The commercial impact from this innovation is to allow for complex waste streams that contain multiple materials, such as textiles, to serve as the source of raw materials for the manufacture of new goods in a way that is cost advantaged. This gives those businesses that use such raw materials a sustainable alternative and importantly, a lower-cost, efficiently produced material. In this way, there will be significant incentive for the reuse of thousands of tons of material that today either goes to landfills, oceans, or is incinerated for energy, a very low value application. A funded, successful project will yield an entirely new framework for recycling of complex, multi-component materials.    

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to develop novel technologies for fractionating complex wastes. Multi-component wastes such as textiles represent upwards of 4% of total landfill volume. Today, there does not exist technology for recovering the high-value materials that are in these wastes. The proposed project intends to develop a new approach using chemical techniques as opposed to simple melt recycling to enable the value-added recycling of high value polymers from such wastes. Chemical process development will take place in order to take the current status of the technology to implementation in a pilot plant. The main technical objective of the proposal is to develop the process so as to produce large amounts of consistent, high purity product. Materials such as polyester and nylon cannot be separated from natural or cellulosic fibers such as cotton or other textile materials. The goals of the research are to develop the proposers' current process for fractionating the synthetic resins with an emphasis on achieving high purity products at larger volumes. To this end, various chemistry and chemical engineering techniques will be investigated for exclusion of impurities from end product polymer at the kg scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Ambercycle was awarded NSF SBIR Phase II funding to further develop our technology that produces virgin-grade polymers from high-volume mixed wastes, including carpet, apparel, and building materials. Throughout the Phase II project, Ambercycle has achieved significant advancements in the purification of polymer materials. These advancements have expanded the range of feedstocks that can be processed and improved the quality of the materials produced by the Ambercycle process, which can be reintroduced into brand supply chains.

The demand for virgin-grade resin and filament yarn derived from post-consumer PET has been steadily increasing, with limited companies capable of supplying high-grade materials to meet the growing market needs. As the textile industry continues to expand, there is an urgent demand for circular materials that surpasses the current and projected availability within the required timeframe. Ambercycle's process and regenerated polyester products directly address this market need and enable apparel brands to transition towards more sustainable supply chains.

During the Phase II project, we successfully transitioned the technology for separating PET from mixed waste from a proof-of-concept stage to a well-developed, scalable process that operates semi-continuously. We have established representative small-scale research systems to evaluate various feedstock types and develop the process using different mixed feedstocks. The Ambercycle process has undergone further refinement and engineering to ensure the produced material achieves a quality equivalent to virgin-grade, while also enhancing process efficiency and versatility to accommodate a wider range of waste textile inputs. Additionally, substantial progress has been made in converting Ambercycle resin into 100% pure Ambercycle PET yarn, which will be reused by global apparel brands that share our vision of creating a truly closed circular system in the textile industry.

Our technology represents a groundbreaking achievement as it is the first time post-consumer waste textile materials have been successfully transformed into fine-denier yarns suitable for critical apparel applications.As such, we have demonstrated that our technology is capable of facilitating circularity within the fashion industry and is ready to be scaled up for commercialization.


Last Modified: 07/14/2023
Modified by: Mubasher Ahmed
